destination.title: A city where life is sweet and living is easy

content.intro:
All the serenity of Nice is captured in the evening as the sun sets on Castle Hill and Mount Boron, while you walk along the citrus-coloured facades of the Old City and stroll through its vivid shopping aisles...

The Niçois don't just love their city they are in love with it.
And how not to succumb to it? There is so much beauty in Nice; it is like a mosaic of lights and movements where the sea breeze of the Baie des Anges breathes life into the paving stones. Take just the harbour area, where the pastels are bright and the jostling spars of sailing boats sing out their international ports of call. In the shadows of trees scented with the lemon and orange flavours of their fruits, you can sense the promise of this seaside resort's vitality.
Nice is like a huge villa nestled in the open, and all the Niçois will tell you that you must go outdoors to live here. Real life is outside, found in a walk along 'The Prom', for its clarity and transparency. A way of life is at work in this city, which softens the sadness of existence. Time here seems to be denser and richer than elsewhere, like the light, which one feels could be drawn in with both hands, given how it flows in such abundance. Nice is the emotional homeland of all great sun-worshippers!
Its heart balances between sea and mountain, between snowy slopes and fiery pebble beaches. But here too is 'Cultura Terra', as the kitchen gardeners of the Cours SaleySaleya a farmer's market proudly tell you in nissard the local dialect who are so tanned and hale that you might imagine them just back from an odyssey or a crusade.
There are so many stories and anecdotes to gather along with all these vegetables bursting with sunshine and bouquets of flamboyant bird of paradise flowers. Consider, for example, how it is that Nice has such endurance. 'From its many green lungs,' suggests a passer-by, muttering to himself, 'and from the sea, the sea!'

content.title: Le Martinez: legendary hotel on La Croisette

introduction.small: A favourite with film stars, the Hôtel Martinez – the very essence of the French Riviera and the newest jewel in “The Unbound Collection by Hyatt” – has a fresh new look.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Martinez: legendary hotel on La Croisette

paragraphs.text:
Opened in 1929 by businessman Emmanuel Martinez, the Hôtel Martinez has long been the grandest hotel on the French Riviera. Today, the seven-storey building still towers tall and proud above the iconic Promenade de la Croisette. Now part of the Hyatt group, talented designer Pierre-Yves Rochon has restored all of the hotel's communal areas, along with its 409 rooms and suites, to their former glory and beyond.

Step through the glass doors and prepare to be captivated by the sight of the vast lobby, worthy of a fairytale palace straight out of the Arabian Nights. Under the vintage chandelier, the sweeping staircase – walked by a whole host of film stars – perfectly captures the hotel's Art Deco style. Outside, the Jardin du Martinez, an oasis of lemon and olive trees, makes a fabulous setting for evenings of jazz music and generous outdoor buffets. Back inside at the Michelin-starred restaurant La Palme d'Or, chef Christian Sinicropi skilfully showcases local ingredients in inventive dishes. It is worth noting that the hotel has achieved “Green Globe” certification for its commitment to sustainability, and its tireless efforts to improve its environmental credentials.

After a relaxing, refreshing visit to the luxurious 900 sqm spa on the top floor, what could be better than finding yourself a spot on the Plage du Martinez, looking out over the Mediterranean and Lérins Islands? It is, quite simply, the best place on the French Riviera to see and be seen.

Hôtel Martinez

06400 Cannes

https://www.hyatt.com/en-US/hotel/france/hotel-martinez/jcagh

Rooms: from 290 EUR

content.title: The Deck Hotel, tribute to the French Riviera

introduction.small: The rooms look like cabins and the bar uses the codes of French Riviera beaches. This hotel of the Old Nice exudes Mediterraneanness.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Deck Hotel, tribute to the French Riviera

paragraphs.text:
Displaying blue, white and grey tones, the Deck Hotel pays tribute to the French Riviera. The hotel's soothing design draws from its surroundings, in the very heart of Old Nice and only a few steps from the lively Promenade des Anglais and seafront. Each room has been drawn like a beach or boat cabin - families will favour the suite with terrace that welcomes four people. The tribute goes on at the hotel's bar, complete with floodlit patio, which is ideal for breakfast in the sun or a snack at any time of the day accompanied with a cup of coffee grown in Central America. Those looking for a working space will favour the "Greek lobby" and its décor inspired by pebble beaches: from the Cyclades to the Mediterranean in a heartbeat! If the Deck Hotel multiplies references to the sometimes expensive-looking Riviera, room prices remain very affordable, especially during low season.

content.title: La Halle gourmande, gastronomy on track

introduction.small: In the disused Gare du Sud train station, a metamorphosis has taken place: a trendy place is born, gathering about thirty food stalls that attracts all food lovers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Halle gourmande, gastronomy on track

paragraphs.text:
In Nice, the former Gare du Sud has risen from its ashes. Train traffic was discontinued in 1991 but food lovers have now taken over the gigantic building. Built for the 1899 Paris world fair, the huge metallic structure (18m high!) shelters food stalls. Thai and Indian food, burgers, sushi, pizzas, stuffed vegetables, coffee shop, fine dining… Various brands of both national and international statures rub shoulders with local restaurateurs, favouring regional products over a 2,500-sqm area. Once you choose a lucky winner, you only need to take a seat under one of the majestic trees taking centre stage amid this industrial setting. The mezzanine too makes best of that retro feel, offering shopping opportunities among a vintage decoration shop, thrift stores and local craftsmen. Keep an eye on the programming: on weekends, cultural events make the Halle Gourmande one of Nice's must-go-to.

content.title: Food-cocktail pairings at Edusa

introduction.small: Near the port of Nice, Edusa's fusion food leaves wine on the side in favour of mixologist-approved pairings.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Food-cocktail pairings at Edusa

paragraphs.text:
At first glance, Edusa looks like a classic French bistro with its long bench seat and Thonet chairs that never go out of style. However, you will soon notice that the high stools around the counter have been replaced by Costa Rican wooden swings, and that numerous exotic items subtly add to the decoration. This mix of styles is actually indicative of Edusa's culinary offer, which makes it a goal to have you travel around the world with a bite. And yet, the true specificity of this address lies elsewhere: forget about canonical wine-food pairings, and make way for cocktails instead - enjoyed in moderation, of course. Here, the Thai sea bream tartare with coconut and pomegranate goes hand in hand with a basil and cucumber syrup gin tonic. The fish burger served with a green pea and mint sauce is accompanied by white martini, limoncello and blackcurrant syrup, while the king prawn risotto is best enjoyed with white rum, peach liquor, lemon and lavender drink. Mixology is starting to earn its place in the world of gastronomy, and Edusa is a proud figurehead.

content.title: Relive the Prohibition days at Old Sport Club

introduction.small: Hidden just a few steps away from Nice's port, the Old Sport Club is a speakeasy-like cocktail bar where you will feel like an insider.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Relive the Prohibition days at Old Sport Club

paragraphs.text:
First, you will have to show some credentials to get into Nice's first speakeasy. Once you are registered online, the Old Sport Club's secret address will be sent to you by email. Near the port and Place du Pin, you will go through a secret and unusual entrance, hidden inside a photo booth! Discover the cosy and subdued setting of this cocktail bar, with leathered fleece-lined armchairs and sofas around the counter. The atmosphere will take you back to the American Prohibition days and its speakeasies. The menu offers eight cocktails only, favouring quality over quantity, and changes every season. With the use of ingredients such as beef stock, mustard, crème fraiche and egg whites in the drinks, the recipes prove to be quite original and add a touch of fantasy to an already unforgettable experience!

content.title: Waka Bar, when Nice and the Maori spirit meet

introduction.small: On Nice's seafront, the Waka Bar reveals itself through an atypical cocktail menu and an environment halfway between the Mediterranean and New Zealand.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Waka Bar, when Nice and the Maori spirit meet

paragraphs.text:
Under the brick arches of a ponchette - typical fisherman house, the Waka Bar radiates a very welcoming atmosphere characteristic of New Zealand. Behind the counter, bottles of alcohol have been displayed like books on a bookshelf, the high perched ones being accessible with a ladder. Cocktail enthusiasts take it easy in this pub where "fun" rings like a mantra - to a degree you can barely fathom during rugby games, as the whole bar comes together as one to the sound of the All Blacks' haka.
Better served with a fish & chips or a burger, the signature drinks - to be enjoyed in moderation obviously - will be hard to choose from: try the delicate Dark'n'Stormy (rum and Jamaican ginger beer), the regressive Real Slim Shady (rum, coffee liquor, banana, milk and M&M's), or why not go for the giant Zombie Kraken (three different rums, pineapple, lime, passion fruit purée and Angostura bitters). The staff speaks English and will be able to guide you depending on your mood and taste.

content.title: The sea in your plate at the Bistrot du Port

introduction.small: In the expert hands of José Orsini, the Bistrot du Port offers you good-quality, unpretentious Mediterranean cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The sea in your plate at the Bistrot du Port

paragraphs.text:
On the Nice port, make sure you make it in past the front of Bistrot du Port. If it looks like nothing much, it is hiding cuisine whose reputation extends well beyond Nice itself. Since 2000, the Orsini family has been at the reigns of this restaurant that highlights fish and Mediterranean savours with José in the kitchen. Before opening this restaurant, the chef followed a remarkable path with a few years next to Alain Ducasse then on to the French Prime Minister's residence, Matignon, in the 1990s.

Sitting on the terrace to make the most of the Niçois sun, relish fresh products while watching the boats sailing to and from Corsica. On the menu, local zucchini gazpacho, crispy sweetbread or a fried calamari salad, as well as the famous fishermen's pot. To end on a sweet note, do not miss out on the delicious dark chocolate fondant!

content.title: The Niçois tradition can be tasted at L'Escalinada

introduction.small: To savour grandmothers' recipes in Nice, there is no better place than L'Escalinada. Home cooking with scents of the South.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Niçois tradition can be tasted at L'Escalinada

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of the old Nice, L'Escalinada is a favourite place for locals and tourists alike. When the sun is up, the terrace is out, and its charm will impress you. In front of the stone facade, the tables are covered with red and white chequered tablecloths. Inside, the restaurant resembles a tavern and makes you go back 50 years with its red-leather banquettes. The smiling welcome completes the warm atmosphere of L'Escalinada. In the kitchen, everything is homemade with the good taste of terroir. Henri Cagnoli delights you with traditional Niçois recipes. Try the fisherman stew with homemade rouille sauce, veal piccata with Marsala or Niçois meatballs. You can also opt for ravioli, gnocchi and fresh pasta with pesto for a little Italian touch.

content.title: Le Galet, a seaside restaurant

introduction.small: After having visited the old town of Nice and dipped your feet in the clear water, settle into the terrace of Le Galet restaurant.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Galet, a seaside restaurant

paragraphs.text:
Your visit to Nice will not be complete without a visit to the Promenade des Anglais, where the Mediterranean will bring you a bit of fresh air under a cloudless sky. This is where you will find Le Galet restaurant. The white and blue decor with wood and pebbles (galets in French) establish a well-defined maritime identity.

The cuisine brings together Italian and French flavours. On the menu, oven baked pizzas, but also veal tartare with artichokes or crusted-pink tuna with Sichuan pepper. And of course, you absolutely have to try the pan bagnat, the local speciality! To finish in perfection, choose the delicious homemade chocolate profiteroles. When lunch is over, you can go to the restaurant's private beach. Protected by the parasols, you can make the most of a lazy afternoon with regular trips between your deckchair and the sea.

content.title: La Table Alziari, just like home, only better

introduction.small: A hidden spot near rue François Zanin, La Table Alziari presents authentic cuisine that you will find delicious.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Table Alziari, just like home, only better

paragraphs.text:
Let the charm of Old Nice operate, and venture off into the alleyways to discover a perfect little restaurant for a lunch break or to relax in the evening. The yellow and green colours with orange-coloured tablecloths remind you of the southern sun. The front of the restaurant in ochre with ironworks promises a warm family spot.

Pasta al pesto, braised veal belly, pizzas and stuffed vegetables, such are the typical dishes of the region that you can share with friends on the terrace of this little restaurant a few metres from René Socca, another well-known restaurant famous for its traditional socca, a chickpea-flour made regional speciality that is at once soft and crispy. After your meal at La Table Alziari, head to visit the baroque Saint Martin Saint Augustin Church, one of the oldest in Nice that is very much worth the detour.

content.title: La Réserve de Nice, the address in Nice for epicureans

introduction.small: An exceptional spot of refined cuisine for an unequalled gustatory experience!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Réserve de Nice, the address in Nice for epicureans

paragraphs.text:
La Réserve de Nice invites you for a gourmet meal with a panoramic view of the Bay of Angels. This legendary restaurant is something of an institution on the Riviera: it dates back to 1862, and has been entirely refurbished in an Art Deco-inspired style. It sits on the promenade at the entrance to the harbour, with terraces overlooking the Mediterranean making it an exceptional location. This is an essential address that will not leave you indifferent, a place to hurry to for a lunch in the sun or a dinner with a view of the sunset. The inventive and creative cuisine of chef Jérôme Cotta who sources exclusively fresh products from the market, will seduce you with its colours and southern accents. You can enjoy the red tuna tataki with shiso tartare, the Riviera ravioli or the free-range guinea fowl, then finish with a lemon tart. Delicious!

content.title: Chez Pipo, anything for socca

introduction.small: This little shop, nestled in the harbour district, has the reputation of having the best socca in the city—the star of the restaurant.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chez Pipo, anything for socca

paragraphs.text:
A stone's throw from Nice Harbour and just out of the way of the flow of tourists, Chez Pipo has deep roots in the culinary heritage of Nice. Here they serve delicious socca, a recipe made with chickpea flour and olive oil that probably arrived in town by sea with Genoese immigrants in the 19th century. The pancake is to be eaten hot with your hands, sprinkled with pepper and accompanied by a simple glass of rosé.

Chez Pipo also offers other Niçois specialties, pan bagnat, pesto soup as well as Swiss chard pie for dessert. You will have to be patient as the place is always full, yet can enjoy some tapenade toasts and dried tomatoes while waiting. Sit in a booth in the dining room, or on the terrace, wherever you can, provided you can taste the golden socca! And for those who will not make it to the port, Steeve Bernardo, the boss of Chez Pipo, has opened a branch in the Nice airport.

content.title: Meandering around Mediterranean Romanticism on Castle Hill

introduction.small: The thousand-year-old birthplace of the city of Nice, the 'cradle of the sun' itself, according to the Niçois, the legendary hill overlooks the old-town neighbourhood like a floating island.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Meandering around Mediterranean Romanticism on Castle Hill

paragraphs.text:
Narrow alleys and multiple stairways with worn steps punctuate the ascent to the site.

Here, nature and human vestiges have combined over the centuries to create a romantic tableau with Provençal tones. Emotions are intense as one ambles about here, leaving the impression of having travelled through the setting of a tale. Here and there the undergrowth is open to the breeze, caressing the face, revealing the most beautiful landscapes of Nice. However, the highlight of the place is the waterfall where the waters of the Vésubie pour down, like a curtain, their show never ceasing to provide pleasure. The panoramic viewpoint from the Bellanda Tower will offer you a vista that embraces all the shades of blue of the bay's arc throughout the day. The contrast between the play of the roofs of Nice and the extent of the impassively peaceful sea is striking.

On a windy day, if you hold on to the balcony rail and let yourself be carried away by the breeze, you might sense yourself on the deck of an ocean liner heading out to sea.

content.title: Nice Opera House: La Traviatta, in its original decor

introduction.small: The Opéra Nice Côte d'Azur is a lyric theatre with programming as modern as it is audacious.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Nice Opera House: La Traviatta, in its original decor

paragraphs.text:
The comfort is palpable upon entering the Baroque decor that clothes the place. Have fun trying to work out the mythical figures that cover the walls, such as the sun chariot racing full speed across the ceiling and the muses frozen in mannequin poses.

Once in the showcase of the theatre, the feeling of having entered a Baroque cocoon will brighten your evening. It's hot, but not too hot, the small boxes of bright red velvet reminiscent of boudoirs. From the main room, they look like nests dug into the walls. Sitting on chairs as old as Stravinsky, in an electric atmosphere smelling of wax and the antique, the wait here is a ritual that is savoured. Especially thanks to the presence of Catherine Segurane, the legendary heroine of Nice, one of whose exploits adorns the stage curtain.

And indeed, once that curtain is lifted, the atmosphere may seem somewhat licentious for an opera. The silence is fragile, broken by a few chuckles…

content.title: Strolling through the alleys of the Franciscan monastery of Cimiez

introduction.small: Among the curiosities to discover in Cimiez, the Franciscan monastery offers the incomparable luxury of a gorgeous view of Nice from on high.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Strolling through the alleys of the Franciscan monastery of Cimiez

paragraphs.text:
The monastery affords a stunning view over the city, but also reflects a whole section of its history, so that you will leave feeling you have rediscovered it.

Its Italian garden breathes and pulsates, especially in the high season. There, a young brother in a tunic sprinkles water on purple flowerbeds, while sun-kissed roses extend their petals for your attention. Towards the cloisters, Sunday sermons resound. A few pergolas, as old as they are leafy, lend you their shade, allowing you to enjoy the music of the fountains dotted here and there. A detour to the cemetery will not in any way cloud your afternoon. Considered by some as the 'palace' of the genre, it houses within its walls the mausoleums and chapels of the oldest patrician families of Nice. Carrera marble and Turbie limestone give it a surprising aesthetic coherence, which will delight your artistic sensibility.

content.title: The Nice Excelsior: where the rooms are like a journey…

introduction.small: Barely having had time to tread down the cobblestones of Nice, the Nice Excelsior is there to welcome you to the cosy atmosphere of its Belle Époque building.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Nice Excelsior: where the rooms are like a journey…

paragraphs.text:
Back from your walk, the facade of the building will indeed draw your attention. However, what you need for relaxation is the private garden of the hotel, which features many attractions, such as a pond surrounded with Mediterranean species. There is also a patio open from 5:00 p.m. whose warm terrace is a fine place to await the evening.

Each room has its own postcard theme and colour. In addition to offering all the comfort you would expect of such a place, you will appreciate the French windows that perfectly filter out the strong rays of the Nice sun.

The beds are fabulous, while some features may make you smile, like the night tables, for example, which are reminiscent of old travel trunks, or the well-chosen literary quotations, discreet and touching odes to the Nice region.

content.title: The ‘Promenade des Anglais': sunset strip

introduction.small: La Promenade des Anglais, or the ‘Prom' in Niçois, doesn't need to show its credentials, as it is the Mediterranean's sunny stroll of strolls.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The ‘Promenade des Anglais': sunset strip

paragraphs.text:
More or less random entertainment and cultural events give it its salt and serendipity. You almost never know beforehand what surprises await you along its seven kilometres.

White wooden pergolas and ample palms shade parts of the walk at regular intervals, so cool off in their shadows. Hats are a must, if only for the look. The palaces push out their facades and their magnificence to try, unsuccessfully, to distract you from the most exciting celebrity here, which is the sea itself. Take in the spray and the winds that come from the sea on the cool, blue chairs. Then day dream while contemplating the Mediterranean itself, your attention balanced on the thin thread of the horizon.

By the end of the day, so many visions will have come to illuminate your walk like the setting sun, whose rays seem to repaint the bay and the Nice sky in dreamy tones.

content.title: The Saint Paul: window onto the sunny streets of Saint-Paul-de-Vence

introduction.small: This charming boutique hotel is a pearl of the Riviera and the embodiment of Provençal art and lifestyle

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Saint Paul: window onto the sunny streets of Saint-Paul-de-Vence

paragraphs.text:
This Relais & Chateaux hotel is located in the highest part of the town, two hundred yards from the fortifications. You get there by following the winding course of an ascending lane. The hotel appears as an authentic Provençal house full of charm, with ivy dressing certain facades.

In full harmony with the architectural soul of the village of Saint-Paul-de-Vence, the building is on a human scale, with two low-ceilinged salons. Decor is both classic and authentic, dominated by white, brown, and golden tones that will put you at ease.

Everything exudes comfort and the clean scent of stone. The massive ancient fireplaces keep us coming back in winter to snuggle into one of the deep, comfortable armchairs. Meanwhile, the rooms and suites overlook the plain, whose roads lead your eyes to the Mediterranean itself. The gastronomic restaurant and its terrace set up between the restanques (terraced pieces of land with a step-like effect) are an invitation to spend a delightful moment.

content.title: Strolling the three markets of the Cours Saleya

introduction.small: In the heart of the historical district, on the Cours Saleya, the maze of markets offers the best products and fragrances, but more especially tons of surprises.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Strolling the three markets of the Cours Saleya

paragraphs.text:
The market is a festival that knows no end. Slip into the crowd toward the bouquets of the flower market. In the shadow of their pretty stalls, draped in colourful stripes, the flower ladies invite you in.

On Monday, head to the flea market, which will test your skills as a bargain hunter. Each stall here is a little theatre, hosted by colourful characters. Aged furniture of scented woods, bizarre trinkets with forgotten uses, musical silverware…as long as you embrace this joyful mess, you will leave with your arms full of treasures. Catch one of the many threads of scents floating in the aisles and you're in the market for fruits and vegetables, a timeless mosaic of small booths filled to the brim with vigorous seasonal products. Take them with both hands, and taste them. Here, every whim of the senses is allowed! Along the way, follow the sound of Teresa's booming voice, it seems she sells the plumpest cherries in the market.

content.title: The Bible's message according to Chagall: an almost kaleidoscopic journey

introduction.small: Taking the form of a rotunda straight out of a Cubist painting, the Marc Chagall museum was born of the artist's desire to gather his works of religious inspiration in one place

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Bible's message according to Chagall: an almost kaleidoscopic journey

paragraphs.text:
The permanent exhibition has the largest public collection of works by Marc Chagall (more than 800 paintings, gouaches, drawings, etc.) in the world.

The 17 paintings that illustrate the Bible's message were inspired by Genesis, Exodus and the Song of Songs, and emerge through a sensitive prism that is absolutely unique. Looking through Chagall's eyes is like a kaleidoscopic journey to the boundaries of colour and representation. In the auditorium, the intense brightness of the stained glass delivers a fantastic show. The mythological figures captured in the glass seem to dance under the effect of changing rays of light. On recital days, the music veils the pieces with a light musical background that enhances appreciation of the collection.

The rest of the time, a quasi-religious peace reigns in the different rooms, whose curious configurations comprise the visit. Upon leaving, the oft-neglected green areas that surround the rotunda exude serenity, offering an ideal setting for reflecting upon the works.

Musée national Marc Chagall

06000 Nice

content.title: The MAMAC and the Villa Arson: two contemporary art centres

introduction.small: With its four towers faced with Carrara marble, the MAMAC is something of a Niçoise citadel for modern and contemporary art.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The MAMAC and the Villa Arson: two contemporary art centres

paragraphs.text:
The Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art (MAMAC) has a collection of 1,000 works that tell the story of artistic creation from the 1960s to the present. Their diversity (painting, sculpture, installations, etc.) sustains interest and curiosity throughout the visit. The venue is composed of a string of pristine air-conditioned rooms whose whiteness brings out the vibrant colours of the great works all the more strongly. Do not under any circumstances miss those devoted to Pop Art and New Realism. There is a surprise in store if you take a moment to breathe in the fresh sea breeze of the bay from one of the building's viewpoints. Yves Klein's Wall of Fire is there, a lone masterpiece. In the same vein, though a little less central, the Villa Arson is an art museum, elite school, and research institution for contemporary art, all in one. Its more open and less linear exhibition space alternates Italian gardens and interiors. There are 1,000 works, against a backdrop of freedom in artistic expression, which offer a challenge how much so is up to you to determine.

content.title: Welcome Hotel: the poet's point of view

introduction.small: Recognisable by its pink facade barred with four blue lines, the Welcome Hotel has been contemplating its reflection in the tranquil turquoise waters of Villefranche for more than four generations.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Welcome Hotel: the poet's point of view

paragraphs.text:
Just 20 minutes from Nice city centre, the hotel is adjacent to the Villefranche-sur-Mer Provençal market, whose scents rise in streams to the windows. It also sits directly on the waterfront, where the sea is so quiet that it barely sways the sleepy masts moored there. You will get to enjoy delicate little touches throughout your stay, like the chocolates carefully deposited on the pillow by invisible hands.

Of all the special moments that punctuate your stay, there is a plentiful, refined breakfast, which can be enjoyed on a balcony where it looks as though the sea itself might touch it. The general mood of the port soothes and transports.

In the evening, music reigns on the terraces: an invitation from the port to come down and browse like a poem, as Cocteau, who stayed in this exceptional place several times, away from all commotion, might say.

content.title: La Petite Maison, where celebrity rhymes with conviviality

introduction.small: La Petite Maison is the perfect stopover when exploring the colourful and sometimes blustery streets of Nice's old quarter.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Petite Maison, where celebrity rhymes with conviviality

paragraphs.text:
Customers all agree that this restaurant is embodied in the form of its truculent chef, Nicole. She is a strong character who has made the reputation of this genuine Niçoise culinary institution, and is considered a 'personality' of the neighbourhood.

Upon entering, the conclusion is clear. Local products are widely highlighted and absolutely to die for; Nicole's artichoke salad is beyond belief. In line with the kitchen, the service is rather rustic. Here, no fuss! The patron has wanted to make her restaurant a theatre, so, on party nights by candlelight, you will find the most famous stars and politicians of this world at the next table.

Some evenings, thanks to a concert or a movie that has won the support of the whole assembly, the atmosphere glows, as trendy and connected, as it is warm.

content.title: Comptoir du Marché: as though you were already seated

introduction.small: A ‘just back from the market' atmosphere defines this unusual and remarkable restaurant that offers discoveries of Mediterranean bistronomy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Comptoir du Marché: as though you were already seated

paragraphs.text:
The Formica furniture with blue and yellow tones places you directly in a Provençal kitchen of the 1950s.

At first glance, the place may seem a bit noisy, but you get accustomed to it – it's all part of the Comptoir du Marché's convivial atmosphere. Time-worn shelves filled to the brim with cans of sardines give it a charm you will not find anywhere else, as does its open kitchen, from which the sounds of cooking and delicious aromas escape. The waitresses dancing through this period decor are dynamic, graceful, and caring.

As for the menu – featuring dishes like beetroot-cured salmon gravlax, and seared duck breast – it is simply exquisite. On your plate, you find the same perfumes, the same vegetables that coloured the morning Saleya market stalls. If freshness is aromatic, the Comptoir is fragrant. Accompany these fragrances with wines of real character the bottles are just waiting to be set on your table.

content.title: Chez René Socca: good mood on tapas stools

introduction.small: René Socca is a legend in Nice, so you cannot pass in front of the restaurant without stopping, if only to take a look at the menu.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chez René Socca: good mood on tapas stools

paragraphs.text:
It must be said that the local socca (a thin, unleavened chickpea pancake, whose recipe, here, is jealously guarded) is an institution. Located in the heart of the old town, at the intersection of two charming lanes, the property is a haunt of artists and gourmets.

Day and night, the place is always in full swing, as if the opening were an event that should never stop being celebrated. There is always a warm excitement in the shadow of the red canopy that houses the tables and dancing stools.

On the menu, you eat on the go or on the terrace, and can expect a festival of local delights. Between the socca and pissaladière (onion pie) coming out of the oven just before you, and the pans bagnats overflowing with colours and freshness, you'll have your fill.

content.title: Castel Plage Restaurant: like being on an island

introduction.small: You will immediately recognise the small entrance of Castel Plage by the small canopy that houses the attractive menu.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Castel Plage Restaurant: like being on an island

paragraphs.text:
A few steps down, there is a warm pebble beach where the waves melt upon the shore. Branches are festooned with ivy under parasols where tables are set. There, olive trees are frozen in the postures of ancient actors. Everywhere bucolic bouquets perfume the breeze that caresses the tables.

You may think you are in the idyllic setting of a deserted island that looks like a small Olympus and it is not the appearance, at sunset, of the Cap d'Antibes that will break the spell. Castel Beach is one of the few restaurants where the gentle waves of Nice appear so close to your table, the theme of the sea seems to be played just for you.

On the menu, you will discover a cuisine with very Provençal temptations, - roasted seabass in olive oil, seafood linguini or a simple and delicious Swiss chard pie for dessert - and service of a rare delicacy for a beach establishment. It's up to you to decide, but the beach rolls out a carpet for you that is difficult to refuse.

content.title: Villa Kilauea: like a small retreat in the hinterland

introduction.small: Climb the stairs that lead to Villa Kilauea and you will be welcomed as a friend. It is the little touches that make the difference, and Nathalie and Gerard are indeed generous in that regard.

paragraphs.text:
These friendly hosts know the area like the backs of their hands and putting you at ease is their specialty. At the same time, everything here has been thought of for your well-being, like breakfast, prepared in the half-light of dawn by Nathalie. The Villa Kilauea is the ideal retreat for relaxation. Take time to read quietly in the shade of the aromatic pine trees, lulled by the refrain of cicadas.

The bell tower of the chapel of Saint-Jeannet, barely higher than the pine forests, hails you from the infinity pool. In the background, there are mountains, large green waves on the always-azure coastal-sky canvas. Lying in the garden or relaxing in the Jacuzzi, the Nice night will appear as to have never before been so full of stars.

content.title: Visiting the old town via its art galleries

introduction.small: Nice has been a muse throughout its rich history and is still a major source of vitality and inspiration in the Riviera artistic landscape.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Visiting the old town via its art galleries

paragraphs.text:
There are a great number of art galleries, famous and discreet, that line the maze of narrow streets. At the beginning of your walk, the Ferrero Gallery continues the mission given it by its founder, which was to exhibit the new leaders of the School of Nice. Compared to the activity in full swing on the street outside, the space evokes a sanctuary.

A few minutes away, not far from Nice Cathedral, a visit to the studio and gallery of artist Sylvie T, where the sketch artist tells tales of her travels in a rainbow of watercolours and takes what is already a beautiful walk to the next level. Passionate about Nice and with an indefatigable zest for life, she will be only too pleased to show you her pastel-coloured impressions of her beloved city.

Further north, towards the Notre-Dame de Nice, do not miss out on a visit to Eva Vautier's gallery. Vautier grew up surrounded by artists – her father's friends – and with this gallery, she is aiming to make art more accessible. She has held six major exhibitions every year since 2013, as well as special events such as experimental gigs and dance shows, all of which only serve to make the iconic gallery's immense collection even more diverse.

content.title: Villa Victor Hugo: sunlight and shadow

introduction.small: The Villa Victor Hugo welcomes you with a beautiful Belle Époque facade, promising a stylish stay.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Villa Victor Hugo: sunlight and shadow

paragraphs.text:
Although located just a stone's throw from the lively Place Massena, the Belle Époque building, identifiable to its angle dome, offers a healthy and serene setting that exudes tranquillity. Your hosts, Stéphanie and Vincent Prieux, have elevated hospitality to an art, thanks to customised service. The decor is contemporary and predominately white, presented in many shades (grey, off-white, pale and pure).

The result is an aesthetic that inspires meditation or inspiration, depending on your mood. As its name suggests, the hotel is placed under the patronage of Victor Hugo, the father of modern French poetry. His verse and most piercing thoughts also sign the immaculate corridors of the hotel in black and ephemeral, handwritten letters. You will find his entire literary universe in the rooms.

Some contain a few surprises, like the one whose window overlooks the Gothic bell tower of the United Protestant Church of Nice.

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Nice
content.introduction: Nice enjoys a Mediterranean and subtropical climate. Average annual high temperatures are usually around 20°C (68°F) and lows rarely drop below negative. Winters (from December to March) are relatively mild and somewhat humid, while summers (from June to September) are hot and dry for the most part, with the Alps shielding the city from north and west winds.

airports.title: Nice Côte d'Azur Airport
airports.description:
The Nice Côte d'Azur Airport is located about 7km (4 miles) west of the city centre.
  • Two terminals:
    • Terminal 1
    • Terminal 2 (Air France)

Getting from the airport to Nice and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible via Avenue des Floralies, as well as Coste, Bellontes and Maîcon streets.
    • Parking facilities are available at each terminal (P2, P4 and G1 at Terminal 1 and P5, P6 and G2 at Terminal 2).
    • Several car rental companies have counters at the airport's arrivals hall.
  • By tram
    • Line 2 runs to the Jean Médécin station in the city centre and Port Lympia station at the port, with trams departing roughly every 8 minutes. Tickets cost EUR 1.50.
    • Line 3 runs to Saint-Isidore and the Allianz Riviera Stadium, with trams departing roughly every 15 minutes. Tickets cost EUR 1.50.
  • By bus
    • Bus 12 runs to Nice/Promenade des Arts. The bus stop is located outside Terminal 1 on the southern carriageway nearest the airport. Buses depart roughly every 20 minutes, and tickets cost EUR 1.50
    • Bus 23 runs to Nice Vallons des Fleurs. Buses depart roughly every 15 minutes, and tickets cost EUR 1.50.
    • Bus Aéroport Direct (formerly Bus 98) runs to downtown Nice (Lycée Masséna) outside Tram 2 operating hours. Buses depart roughly every 20 minutes, and tickets cost EUR 1.50.

 
  • By Taxi
    • Taxi ranks are located outside exit A1 (Terminal 1) and exit A3 (Terminal 2). Fares to the city centre are approximately EUR 32 EUR.
  • By shuttle
    • Free shuttle service between the terminals and the parking facilities, every day from 4:30 a.m. to 12:30 a.m.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, pharmacy, free Internet access (Wi-Fi), currency change and post office available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +33 (0)820 423 333 (charge of a local call, EUR 0.12/minute)
  • Website: https://en.nice.aeroport.fr/

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Nice
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Nice each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: February: Carnival (local)
events.description: The Carnival of Nice, third largest in the world after Rio and Venice, is an opportunity for two weeks of jubilation. During that time, the city centre becomes a huge open-air venue for big parades.

events.title: May 1: Labour Day (national holiday)
events.description: On the first of May, it is customary to offer a sprig of lily-of-the-valley to close ones. Many vendors occupy the pavement on that occasion!

events.title: May 8: Victory Day (national holiday)
events.description: Commemorates the Allied victory in Europe that ended World War II on this day in 1945. Various ceremonies are held around town.

events.title: June 21: Fête de la Musique (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: Also celebrated internationally as World Music Day, for this festival many free concerts featuring all types of music are held in the streets and at various venues around Nice.

events.title: July 14: Bastille Day (national holiday)
events.description: This holiday celebrates the storming of the Bastille prison in 1789, the key event marking the beginning of the French Revolution. It plays as a symbol of the end of the privileges enjoyed by the clergy and the aristocracy. In Nice, the festivities take place on the Promenade des Anglais, where free concerts, activities and a spectacular fireworks display take place late in the evening.

events.title: August 15: Assumption Day (national holiday)
events.description: This celebration, still very popular in Nice, is marked by the faithful with several religious processions and ceremonies through the streets.

events.title: Third weekend in September: European Heritage Days (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: The aim of the European Heritage Days is to open up numerous sites and monuments, many of which are normally closed to the public, such as castles and private collections. A great opportunity for a lovely stroll through the city to admire architectural treasures!

events.title: November 11: Remembrance Day (national holiday)
events.description: On this day, citizens gather at the war memorial in Nice to commemorate the signing of the 1918 Armistice officially bringing an end to the First World War.

events.title: December 31: New Year's Eve (national event)
events.description: On the night of December 31<sup>st</sup>, the atmosphere is particularly festive on the streets of Nice, with families and friends celebrating the new year.
